content.body: foolip: Added the new object-fit values.  Review, please?  Also, dbaron said he has some objections to the values, so we'll see what he has to say.

Hixie, there's a discussion on public-web-security where abarth is arguing CSP is too complicated, but he doesn't seem to have specific examples.  I think you said similar stuff before; do you have specific examples?
It looks way too complicated for authors to me, but I haven't looked closely enough to formulate specific examples.
TabAtkins, you forgot to put scale-down in the syntax list at the top of the spec
TabAtkins, also, the spec needs a "previous version" link, since it does have one
er, top of the section, not top of the spec
AryehGregor: i don't recall examples off-hand, but iirc my reaction was the same as yours
AryehGregor: the key being that it's a security feature
Yeah.
AryehGregor: so complexity leads to security vulns
On the other hand, the inflexibility required by simplicity conflicts with the goal of being deployable without large-scale content changes.
it is a common dilemma
But realistically, you're not going to get XSS protection without doing drastic things like banning inline script, so maybe deployability needs to be deemphasized.
It actually even reminds me a bit of SELinux (although of course orders of magnitude less complicated).  Someone was saying something about how authors should use a policy generator.  :(
And of course, with SELinux, the first advice everyone gives when it goes wrong is "Disable it."
Ideally most of CSP should be reduced to just one on/off switch, like ES5 strict or something.
I should post these ideas to the list, maybe I will tomorrow.
Still catching up on stuff, although thankfully I didn't have to ignore *everything* while I was in Israel (or else I'd really have a lot to catch up on).
heh, i know that feeling
dbaron: Ah, right.  Sorry about missing that.
And I'll add a prev version link.
Hixie: Have you heard of lcamtuf's mangleme?
http://lcamtuf.coredump.cx/mangleme/
zcorpan: webm.html5.org is not yet in bitbucket
ok
http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/progress/Progress.html has a redirect now
thanks to MikeSmith!
MikeSmith++
nice http://richwchan.com/2011/01/25/literally-drawing-the-html-5-logo-in-canvas-with-javascript/
zcorpan: ping
smaug____: pong
zcorpan: so why the need for capturing event listeners if forminput/change would be removed?
sloppiness 2.5 / 7.5 / 3.5 / 3.5 works fine
smaug____: i don't understand the question
zcorpan: you're simon, right?
smaug____: yep
I'm talking about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=11129#c15
oh, do the change and input events bubble?
yes
i assumed that they didn't bubble
ok, then a capturing listener would not be needed for the shopping cart
smaug____: for multiple event handlers, i was considering several <output>s that update their own value when something else is changed
e.g. <output name=amountWithoutTax onformchange=...></output> <ouput name=amountWithTax onformchange=...></output>
again, there could be one input/change event listeners doing that all
yes
I'm having trouble to see the real usefulness of forminput and formchange
I wonder when those were added and what discussion lead to it
i think they've been part of WF2 since 2004 or so
aha, so there might not have been too much discussion about them ...
and no wonder I haven't been able to find related emails
tries again

i think they're mostly there so you can couple your event handler with the <output> tag instead of putting the logic far away from where it's supposed to update the content (and you don't need to name your outputs)
doesn't WebKit have them as well now?
that use case is still rather vague
I think webkit just added them, like few days ago
I don't want to add useless features to web platform, if just possible
I assume that if they were just added to webkit , they could be easily removed
also, with the form="" feature the forminput and formchange events are broadcasted to the controls that are associated with the form even if they're not descendants
there is no content which relies on those events
i don't have a use case in mind though for that
even with form="", if is trivial to just check event.target.form in the event listener
s/if is/it is/
yes, but it's a bit different coding style. not a strong argument to support the events, but still :)
as for valueAsNumber, it might be a bit faster since you don't need to convert to string and back
but do you need speed?
does not seem like the thing that needs an optimization path
yeah, dunno
ah, yeah, valueAsNumber doesn't look too useful either
does Opera implement it?
or webkit?
opera does
seems webkit too
but not firefox 4
but I guess it is not really use anywhere yet
so perhaps there is still chance to get rid of it
file a bug?

annevk: fwiw, I had problems before with trying to get some htaccess working on dev.w3.org and only managed to figure it what worked through trial and error. I think they have something misconfigured on that server
but glad it's working now anyway
did you remove ./ or some such?
or made it into an absolute path?
yeah
and used RedirectMatch instead of Redirect
oh
btw, I also fixed the borkedness that was causing http://es5.github.com/ to load so slowly
if you try it now it should work find
*fine
bypass your cached copy of course
Am I dreaming or is Facebook really encouraging invalid HTML ? http://developers.facebook.com/docs/opengraph
<meta property="og:title" content="The Rock"/>
Yes
They're encouraging fake namespaces too
wtf ?
they should invent a microdata vocab and use that
ah, Facebook
that explains the 3.5% RDFa I saw somewhere
http://tripletalk.wordpress.com/2011/01/25/rdfa-deployment-across-the-web/
Facebook deserves some love for https://github.com/facebook/jsgamebench though
hope they do more of that kind of stuff
oh so that's RDFa
why isn't there any mention of that on the docs ?
<fb:like /> isn't RDFa
but property is
MikeSmith: I heard reports that benchmark isn't very useful, but I haven't confirmed or anything
jgraham: still happy to see them putting resources into developing such tools at all
how do you delete apps on android?
annevk: Testing document.domain requires different domains (not subdomains), right?
jgraham, subdomains is fine
jgraham, with subdomains you can check if they can communicate with each other after setting document.domain, you cannot actually do that with different domains
so how do I declare that my HTML page is using RDFa ?
document.domain is thus a good reason for subdomains :)
annevk: Right, but you need different domains to check that they can't, or something
I'm pretty sure that we have TCs that require multiple domains
(Sigbjorn would know for sure)
well, you want to test publicsuffix maybe
but that requires a more complicated setup
We need subdomains for sure
But I think we also need two domains
annevk: easiest is to just find it in the app drawer, hold it, move it over the trash bin, hold for two seconds until it tells you to release to uninstall
Why is pubsuffix more complex?
how are two domains different though?
other than publicsuffix
Well that is one reason
asks someone who actually knows :)
I'm pretty sure you cannot test publicsuffix with two domaisn
you would want to test all the permutations
from a little bit of googling, rdfa in html5 does not require anything special but validator.nu is not marking rdfa as valid yet
e.g. with some kind of custom DNS setup
is it right?
Rik`, something like that
Right, doing a really good test of pubsuffix is hard
hasather, that does not seem to work :/
oh well
Rik`, the cabal doesn't approve of rdfa
annevk: you can also uninstall from the market, or through Settings > Applications
ah that works

annevk: Sigbjorn's list is "pubsuffix, x-frame-options, crossdomain XSS, cookies, cross-network". Not all apply to W3C ofc but being able to test them is good. Also browsers might have bugs in seperate domains that they don't have in subdomains
there's no real difference though between domains and subdomains
it's just a set of dots DNS
and DNS
e.g. is example.co.uk a subdomain?
Pubsuffix could tell  you that
pubsuffix draws arbitrary lines too
Any spec does ;)
e.g. dyndns.com iirc is a "TLD"
Ms2ger, my point is that apart from pubsuffix there's not really any meaningful difference between domains and subdomains
True
annevk: you saw http://gmailblog.blogspot.com/2011/01/desktop-notifications-for-emails-and.html ?
yeah
does anyone happen to have an URL for an HTML page that's served over IPv6 only (no IPv4 A record)?
s/an URL/a URL/
http://ipv6.google.com/
thanks
I cannot open that, I wonder when I will drop from the interwebs
Gandi got IPv6 routing
I wonder if html5.validator.nu would break if I added an AAAA record for it
at present, it seems that html5.validator.nu itself can't validate http://ipv6.google.com/
hmm
http://googlepublicpolicy.blogspot.com/2010/12/making-copyright-work-better-online.html Google siding with the entertainment industry
bah
annevk: Assuming that browsers work in the same way as specs theorise is not always a great idea
jgraham, is this still about the domain thing?
Yes, I was away
I'm be interested in seeing an implementation that does it wildly different :)
In the end though code will be changed and converged... You cannot really anticipate all possible implementation mistakes everywhere
Right, but I don't really see the disadvantage of giving ourselves the option for cross domain (not subdomain) tests
Rik`: validator.nu did have RDFa support previously, but it was removed
MikeSmith: since so many pages are using facebook stuff, is there some info we can give?
cause right now, it looks like it's not valid at all
jgraham, maybe because you insist there's a difference :)
Rik`: for now, the W3C validator has an option to do XHTML+RDFa checking
those docs are all being served with an XHTML doctype anyway, right?
and namespace declarations for the namespaces that Facebook uses for their properties
MikeSmith: it's HTML
the doctype? or the mime type?
you don't need XHTML to provide a screenshot
mime type
yeah well
MikeSmith: what does XHTML+RDFa actually check?
hsivonen: dunno
I've not actually tried it myself
hsivonen: http://dev.w3.org/validator/htdocs/sgml-lib/REC-rdfa-syntax-20081014/ I guess
MikeSmith: so not checking anything but typos in the names of the attributes?
seems so
essentially
omg some people
what if the moon falls on the earth
i guess that'd be pretty bad

Dear lazy-irc: For a SVG testcase I want to align the bottom of some text (specifically, the bottom of the em-square, or whatever the filled area in the X glyph in Ahem corresponds to) with the bottom of a <rect>
are we assuming it doesn't and build around that?
o_O
jgraham: You can choose the co-ordinate point that text is drawn from in SVG
gsnedders: How?
Including from the baseline
jgraham: I can't remember :P
My normal solution in your position: ask ed.
baseline !== em-square aiui
the em-square goes down to the bottom of baseline
Really? Which baseline? I am just looking at the diagram in the HTML spec
There is a line called the baseline.
It becomes complicated when you use multiple scripts, but that's a separate issue unrealted to this case
notes it is already complicated
doesn't see anything relevant in http://www.w3.org/TR/SVGTiny12/text.html#CurrentTextPosition
decides to pursue a different approach
can you change the templates MediaWiki uses from the Wiki instance itself?
or do you need to change PHP and such somewhere?
annevk, templates are written in wikitext
MediaWiki:Sidebar was the one I wanted to change
navigation was linking to dead pages
hmm. SVG in a big language in terms of vocabulary tokens
hsivonen: looking at sanitation?
zcorpan: yes. I'm assembling lists of interned tokens manually
there's *lots* of tokens
and I'm manually categorizing them as SVG fonts (omitted) and SMIL (behind #ifdef)
one of those tasks that maybe could have used a script, but developing the right script would have taken time considering that it needs to be run once
and the hyphenation vs. camelCase is full of FAIL. Found one bug already.
The interesting thing about scripts that need to be run exactly once is that they always end up being run >>once
Not saying it is worthwhile in this case though
SVG fonts bloats the language by many, many attributes...
they gave me a new iPhone...
annevk: SVG fonts gave you an iPhone?
yeah, didn't work on my Android
aha
hey, it makes sense to me
it's so sad that they compile the Android WebKit without SVG support
gives opportunity for Firefox and Opera I guess, on the bright side
But WebKit supports all of HTML5, including SVG!
Why do they compile it without SVG support?  I've noticed that.
HTML5 on Android doesn't include SVG
http://www.w3.org/mid/q433k65vs00o7509mrpbq1sll9ukt9uoc3⊙hbhd
RELAXNG to JSON
http://www.infoworld.com/d/developer-world/html-the-standard-failed-585 sigh
can't even comment
Man, screw you, Infoworld, and your stupid sign up.
Also: Argh, that post is a giant pile of misconceptions that we already answered in the FAQ.
yeah, it is quite weird
You know the FAQ is a waste of time, right?
Clearly.
I don't think it is
The sort of people with a giant pile of misconceptions will never read the FAQ
I mean, my questions are obviously superior to the plebes.\
And thus, by definition, not frequently asked.
jgraham, well yeah, but it's useful for a lot of other people
Thus I have no need to read the FAQ, QED.
I guess it works to tell people RTFM after the fact
I wonder if Infoworld is read well
and it is very useful to have all that information gathered somewhere
Yeah, having the information is useful
I meant "is a waste of time for the purposes of preventing people from publishing their misconceptions all over the intertubes"
geez
am I really the person that has to explain everything to Leif?
No, you could ignore him like everyone else
jgraham, having an FAQ is useful as a resource to point people to when they ask common questions so that people don't have to keep making up new answers all the time.
Lachy: Right, see what I said about RTFM above
that does not seem too nice at this point, but this does not seem to be going anywhere
annevk: Yeah, what jgraham said.  I just stopped talking to him a long time ago.
I don't think anyone expects all people to read it first before asking silly questions
I think I need to filter him like I do Garrett Smith.
He does have a point, though. Giving a certain feature set an unambiguous name does have its advantages.
Opera 10 has certain features, Opera 11 has certain other features. The Web and HTML is much more complex than that, of course, but I can see where he's coming from.
wilhelm: The infoworld guy or Leif?
The infoworld person.
now has a theory that even mentioning Leif causes the strange vortex of confusion to occur, whereupon all straightforward conversations become mired in twisty logic and disjoint arguments
wilhelm, we should drop versioning in Opera too, and just have the update system work so that it silently updates people to the latest
wilhelm: If you follow the Google philosophy then you don't need that for browsers
It doesn't seem to be doing them any harm
Lachy: Sure. That doesn't work on all platforms, though.
and it is less true for browsers (which are by-definiton single implementation) than for specs
Lachy: You can keep versioning, if the update would be more silent. ^_^
where a single "version" doesn't correspond to anything concrete in the real world
TabAtkins, sure, like Chrome's versoining which exists, but which isn't publicised anywhere
annevk: Re: waves of negative blog comments, jd calls in seagull linking
Yes.
happens to his blog when Gruber links :-)
Presumably after a while Chrome will give up on version numbers entirely
If browsers manage to make versionless UA strings
(well that isn't a precondition exactly, but if the only place you can observe the version number is in the about dialog, it doesn't mean anything anymore)
There are a lot of reasons why versions can't be scrubbed from UA strings, unfortunately
wilhelm, how was it clear with HTML5 what we implemented? seems exactly the same problem

We have a test suite internally testing form interaction. It deliberately tests only the HTML4 feature set (text, password – not number, date, email), but of course adheres to the HTML[5] spec for the technical details. That is a useful distinction.
paul_irish: I thought Mozilla were pushing toward fake versioning
Or maybe no versioning
wilhelm, you think?
wilhelm: Only if it corresponds to some implementation detail
jgraham: in the UA string? eesh. i should dig into that. :/
wilhelm, split feature sets are useful I suppose
wilhelm, but that does not have to do much with HTML4 vs HTML5
paul_irish: What would break if you just froze the UA string at some arbitary point?
nothing would break, but there would be a lot of features/bugs that emerge after that point that would be undetectable.

annevk: Yes. In this particular case, the HTML-1997 feature set was easy to test – the HTML-2009 feature set more difficult. Saying "Let's focus on the HTML4 feature set for now" was a useful shorthand.
you might also be locked in to a buggy codepath, even if the bug was fixed post-freeze. e.g., https://github.com/marijnh/CodeMirror/blob/master/js/editor.js#L7-19
My (biased) experience is that UA sniffing *always* ends badly
agrees
So I am inclined to think that the problems caused by making it harder would be smaller than the problems it causes
wilhelm, fair enough
wilhelm, I guess in the future that would be old vs new :)
wilhelm, the danger is of course that people might look at HTML4 and find bugs relative to that

jgraham: this is what i'm getting at. https://github.com/Modernizr/Modernizr/wiki/Undetectables  basically unless all these things are detectable without using UA.. then authors will need the UA+version for when feature detection doesnt suffice.
paul_irish: or unless UAs implement half baked things
which is the real problem, imo
like webforms UI…
indeed. :)
paul_irish: The flipside of that is that people make broken assumptions based on UA detection. Like "all mobile browsers are webkit"
yes. in 95% of cases, the UA sniff is unnecessary. i'm just saying there is a legit 5% in there.
but.. authors mostly suck. that's why we "deprecated" $.browser in jQuery. basically saying "stay away! figure it out youself, bro!"
some of the undetectables in that page are useless to detect
registerProtocolHandler()
if you detect that it's not supported, what is your fallback ?
waves to paul_irish  - any news re http://html5rocks.com CORS enabled? last time I checked it seemed not to be the case - just wondering when to update http://enable-cors.org/#who
jgraham: the issue is not really about having versionless UA string, but having *all user agents* doing that at the same time :)
indeed there will be massive breakage around
karlcow: I'm not proposing versionless
what do you propose
I'm suggesting you can freeze the version number
mhausenblas: everything at www.html5rocks is Access-Control-Allow-Origin:* now :)
hu? hmmm then I need to check my checker :)
same issue
ha!
ok, true paul_irish www.html5rocks.com is but I checked at html5rocks.com
jgraham: if browsers implementers don't do it at once. There will be no changes
Rik`, you don't always need fallback
annevk: Absolutely. Freezing parsing rules, for example, would be insane. But grouping features together and giving them a name is useful.
is going back to user agent sniffing issues ;) for opera
wow, great! paul_irish! (re. everything at www.html5rocks is Access-Control-Allow-Origin:* )
♥ cors
anyone here happen to have any history with the jw player html5 fallback system?
jgraham, your example seems highly unlikely
jgraham, probably because you do not author a blog :p
I have never seen it done that way
annevk: You really think that no one will consider <header> to be the header for the entire page including the title of the content?
Maybe not on a blog
But in general
well, in that case grouping them is not too problematic
there's only one subject
you would care mostly about the other headings anyway
You would care mostly about the heading that you would lose
i.e. the title of the content
Agreed with jgraham - I think I might do that <header> pattern sometimes.
(rather than the title of the site)
o_O
Can someone please tell me if they have any history with fall back on html5 specifically with jw player?
what was jgraham's example?
thecolor3, doesn't look like it
Ms2ger: yea so it seems
oh, I see it now (caught up on email)
thecolor3, maybe in #html5
will there be an API for NFC? http://venturebeat.com/2011/01/25/iphone-5-ipad-2-nfc/
is fooled by the NFC !== Normal Form C thing yet again
sorry, Near Field Communications
hopes this technology doesn't catch on
Or I will be confused the whole time
Moreso than normal I mean
jgraham: I think you will be confused the whole time ;)
I was too
I was briefly confused before I figured out what was meant.
until I saw vendturebeat.com and Apple product names
5x more NFC than NFC ;)
Hopefully someone figures out that Near Field Communications is not the sort of name you can sell to the mass market
and calls it something else
jgraham: you mean like GPS :p
karlcow: dammit
hehe
I was confused for an entire lunchtime conversation over that.
It doesn't have to be true that you can't sell it, you just have to have them believe it
in fact GPS as the same issue than HTML5, GPS is used for geoip, celltower triangulation, etc. for everything-location-through-waves
To most people, a "GPS" is the thing in your car that tells you where to drive.
votes we rename it Hvísla
since when did I become a member of the press?
yesterday some marketing agency asks my address details for "free" gifts
Since you got a blog and a twitter account
Interesting.
today I get some kind of press release about a code competition and invitation to talk with the CEO if I want more details...
is there a list somewhere?
I want off
You want X-Do-Not-Act-Like-I-Am-A-Journalist
that just leads to the inevitable X-Do-Act-Like-I-Am-A-Journalist-I-Really-Mean-It

"Web developers have tried to compensate for this problem by creating IPv6 -- a system that recognizes six-digit IP addresses rather than four-digit ones." ~http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2011/01/26/internet-run-ip-addresses-happens-anyones-guess/
On that note, though, does anyone know why ipv6 is named ipv6?  It's got 16 bytes, so it's not following the same naming scheme as ipv4, unless they're just taking it mod 10.
...Oh.  It's just version 6, and ipv4 is version 4.  No relation to the byte size at all.
Yes.
I know I've seen some blog software where the italics button produces <em>.  Does anyone know what I'm talking about?
hiptsercat/I still use/ipv5/
I think wordpress does/did that.
Yeah, but the Wordpress blogs I'm looking at don't seem to have markup buttons.
At least in WebKit.
Maybe they do in other browsers?
They do in the article posting interface.
Just not in comment posting.
Ah.
Grr.
I know I've asked this more than once before, but where are some stats on how often various elements are used, more detailed than Google's 2005 study?
http://philip.html5.org/data/tag-count-pages.txt ?
There we go, thanks.
so, uh, anybody have a great idea about how to proceed on http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2011Jan/0415.html ?
I really don't know.  It doesn't make a ton of sense to continue on with the issue if you're trying to raise a larger bug.
foolip_, it seems like you do not need to withdraw it
foolip_, it seems in scope as well... it's just that your solution is slightly more complex
the change I want would conflict with the change Julian wants, so the question is if I can just push for what I want and let the conflicts happen as they may
(though better, imo)

it would seem a bit sneaky if, for example, I just propose this change, Hixie does it, and when Julian's issue has been resolved there's no longer any application/octet-stream to change the wording on
if you are still unsure I would reply and ask that, but I do not think you have to do anything at this point
also, just looking at the size of the changes, my proposal is pretty much guaranteed to draw more objections
if that should happen, how should one interpret that decision when we want to kill Content-Type?
Philip`: you should put a date at the top of this txt file.
foolip_, it can be re-raised
foolip_, if there's sufficient support it will happen that way
nice, selecing Settings from a Gmail desktop notification crashed my chrome
looks around for atwilson
with a baseball bat?
annevk, ok, do nothing it is
any Mozillans in here?
roc, maybe?
it'd be nice to hear if their position on this has changed at all
position on what?
oh that
Racing to the bottom of the poisoned well
that's my line!
Ms2ger, right, dropping right to the bottom instead how slowly and painfully being dragged down, creating a mess along the way :)
I guess we've lost already :)
s/how/of/
right, I think it's easier to just give up and do what IE, Chrome and Safari are already doing
I agree
I don't like it, but I agree
How about we all just implement it, then?
I should mention it to our video guys again to make sure they're not going to rebel though
roc, please do :)
I assume you're already "sniffing" for the difference between audio/ogg and video/ogg anyway :)
that is, just decoding it and seeing what happens
yes of course
although we will have to add new sniffing code since currently we instantiate a decoder based on MIME type
back in a bit

roc, OK, good to know that you're also prepared to give up :)
or should it be :/
MikeSmith, drawImage ?
and <canvas onclick>
question... content: url(image.png); seems to replace the image in WebKit but not Gecko
is this a bug or just not implemented?
(fx 3.6 btw :))
same in the firefox 4 beta 10
twisted`: replace which image?
smaug____: it's a span with text that gets replaced
karlcow: Even better than that, the date is before the top of the text file, in the HTTP header :-p
twisted`: hmm, dbaron should know...
Philip`: :p
(None of my data stuff is really meant to make sense out of its original context)
yep
(which is usually some IRC conversation or email etc)
smaug____: not a big issue I can also do a hide of the text and then do a background
but this looks nice a nicer solution
(and there's too much required context and too many caveats to make the data presentation self-contained)
twisted`: it is possible that content: url(image) isn't implemented
Philip`: you should add
X-Context: "None of this data stuff is really meant to make sense out of its original context"
in the HTTP headers
:p
twisted`: apparently CSS2.1 isn't too strict what should happen with content: url(some_resource)
content isn't implemented on elements, only for pseudo-elements in Gecko
I doubt anyone supports content: url(somepage.html)
ah, right, Ms2ger is most probably right
Presumably it *should* work like an iframe.  But yeah, very underspecified.
Does that work in WebKit already? I thought it was just Opera...
seems to work in webkit
That's vaguely horrifying.
Although I can't say exactly why.
i mean element { content:url(image.png) } works in webkit
Oh, that's not so horrible.
I thought we were talking about HTML.
hmm
well I'll just stick the image directly in it
zcorpan: Though, it doesn't work the way I think it *should*; it doesn't act like a replaced element, but rather like an element with an anonymous child.
just need to figure out if the image of a single-quote I put in the content can be moved around
When I pick up Generated Content I'll figure out whether we can make that automatic or have a switch or what.
TabAtkins: i think it does in opera too
what's happening with svg instead of png
and with html called from svg ?
based on CSS 2.1, content applies only to :before and :after
TabAtkins: iirc there's a good reason for it but i'm not sure what it is
With a difference between |url(image)| and |url(image) ""|?
Ms2ger: That's what I'm thinking, yeah.
I guess that would probably work
has to finish this email, but it seems like a fun thing to test
please don't make content:url() work for anything but images
TabAtkins: maybe it's because it's supposed to be consistent with how content: "foo" url(image) "bar"; would be handled
also, when directly applied 'content' does make some kind of replaced element, no?
maybe I misremembered
zcorpan: Yeah, but it makes it impossible to do actual image replacement, which is annoying.
we should just special case content with a single url()
imo
well annevk that would reverse the snafu
annevk: Yeah, that's what I'd like to do.  I'll explore it later when I pick up the draft, though if anyone wants to forge ahead with an implementation, feel free.
HTML5 would be then included in CSS3
Tab, how many specs are you editing now, and how many are you planning to take up in the near future? :)

Probably the best way is just to blacklist based on UA string.  I don't think there's any way to feature-test there, except possibly by trying to load the image and checking for error events, which is slow.
(note: do not whitelist based on UA string, that's evil)
AryehGregor: I was planning more a whitelist :p browsers I know that support it get the SVG and else... just the PNG
oh, ok, why not?
Whitelisting means your page won't work well with any new browsers that show up.
It will bitrot.
Blacklisting only punishes new browsers if they do the wrong thing and don't support SVG.
Which is unlikely for mainstream browsers at this point.
Whereas the existence of browsers you haven't heard of is basically a certainty.
hmm not possible to say IE =< 9 allowed but the rest not? dunno
Set some value in a conditional comment for IE <= 9, then check if it's set.  If not, add the SVG and hope for the best.
